messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
yes

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
no

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
yes

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
yes

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
okay
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

As the populations across all cities increase, the housing demands are very hard to keep up with. There are apartments that have no vacancies making it hard for people who need to find a home. I used to live close to a college and that also really affected pricing and home availability. The college students drove up the prices and made less homes available to the residents in my city.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

There will be more homes which will give people more options of where to live. I think it will also drive the prices down as less people will be competing for each housing unit. I think the positives outweigh the negatives.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

I think that with all the new construction the affordability will be better as there will be more homes than people looking to move. i think that lack of upzoning is what keeps home and apartment prices going up as we are all competing for the same home resources.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

I think that quality of life will be the same. The character will be more modern, maybe even a bit industrial or overcrowded like bigger cities and downtown areas. However, I think that with increased housing we might see more businesses migrate and thus create a positive change in the economy of that neighborhood/s.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

It will make congestion worse. A lot of the areas in my city are already crowded regardless of the day or time. It will add a lot to commute times. There are also more accidents on the road in my city than 10 years ago so as upzoning happens and more people move, then there will more crowds and traffic.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
I think my local government needs to do a lot of things as I do not agree with a lot of what they are doing and I think they should be limited to the bare essentials.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

I'm concerned about the environment, but at the same time, we can't avoid building and housing people, so it must be done. However, ordinances should still be followed to make sure they work within the environmental limits that are currently in place.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
The positive is that there would be more revenue in the areas with the new housing as there will be more people in that area living and spending time there. I cannot think of a negative impact.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think that current residents should be heard, but they do not own the city nor all the land, so at the end of the day, their voices shouldn't be at the top. What needs to be the determining factor is housing needs and projected data.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
I do not understand. Can you explain it in another way?

How would you describe the relationship between Housing demand and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Anytime I see there is a zoning change request people get up in arms about how they do not want to build more housing and how it will be an eye sore and diminish home values. So, it has a negative effect with local homeowners. Other people and businesses seem to favor it more.

What do you think are the main causes of Support for Upzoning, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

The need for more homes. The lack of available homes. The lack of square footage which demands upzoning. The needs of my city are only growing. I think those of us who support it do so because we see the need for more affordable housing.

Is the effect of Decrease in housing competition on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It takes time to develop as the upzoning areas will not be built overnight nor will they immediately be full to capacity and immediately decrease housing competition. It will slowly develop as people move, go to college, separate, etc and have changes that necessitate moving.

Is the effect of Positive impact outweighs negative on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The positive takes times to see as we won't see how a neighborhood performs until we see the results after 1 or 2 years to see the actual effect on traffic, density, home availability. etc.

Would small changes in New Construction lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Thanks for watching!

How confident are you that changes in Neighborhood character lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that as younger people move into older neighborhoods the support for upzoning increases.

Would small changes in Traffic Congestion lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It would take larger shifts. My city has a lot of horrible roads, lots of one way streets (in small areas but also in more congested areas). My city/state has a lot to improve on when it comes to traffic congestion.

How would you describe the relationship between Urban Density and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think the more urban density the more support as you have a lot more people looking for a home. It is a positive effect as it allows upzoning to occur.

Would small changes in Increased revenue lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Larger shifts. I don't think anyone in my city would care about small changes in the economy or revenue.

Would small changes in Future residents' interests lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I don't think it would matter. People who oppose upzoning will always be opposed regardless of how future residents act or are perceived.

Is the effect of Housing needs on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It takes time to develop as the needs of the city need to change drastically for it to be considered.

How would you describe the relationship between Negative effect on local homeowners and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Strong connection of homeowners opposing upzoning as they are always complaining in the local reddit, neighborhood and even community talks.

Does Need for more homes have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Need for more homes has a positive effect as it directly benefits upzoning and the companies that want to develop those areas. it is a strong effect as the companies building these apartments are money hungry.

How confident are you that changes in Positive effect of upzoning lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Not very confident

Would small changes in Neighborhood performance evaluation lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It would take larger shifts. Homeowners are very resistant to changes in their neighborhood, traffic commute, streets, etc.
What factors affect Population growth, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
Job and education opportunities. With a lot of jobs and education opportunities more people will want to move which will affect population growth

How would you describe the relationship between Single-family neighborhoods and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Single family neighborhoods are always opposed to upzoning. They want their city and neighborhoods to remain quiet, safe, etc. So there is no connection there.

Would small changes in Lower housing prices lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Pricing would not change the support.

Would small changes in Time required for development lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Larger shifts. Communities are extremely resistant to upzoning.

Does Homeowners opposing upzoning have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It has a negative effect and it is a very strong effect. Homeowners in my neighborhood always oppose zoning changes and upzoning

Does Positive Effect have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
That does not make sense

Would small changes in Competition for Resources lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It would take larger shifts as everyone is highly competitive and resistant to change

Would small changes in Quality of life lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It would take larger shifts as people see upzoning as bad.

Does Transportation Systems have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I don't think it has any effect at all.

Is the effect of Migration on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it takes time to develop as you would need to track migration and it's effect.

How confident are you that changes in Opposition to upzoning lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Not confident

How would you describe the relationship between No connection between single-family neighborhoods and support for upzoning and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It has a negative effect and it is a very strong effect. Homeowners in my neighborhood always oppose zoning changes and upzoning

How would you describe the relationship between Commute Times and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Strong connection in a negative way as the streets in my city are all congested past what is reasonable.

How would you describe the relationship between Accidents on Roads and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Strong connection in a negative way as there are more crashes as the population rises

How would you describe the relationship between Accidents on Roads and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes, I would

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
No, I prefer to type

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Yes, this is they way I prefer to answer

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Okay
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
I'm ready
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I strongly support upzoning policies. I live in California where the housing shortage is a major crisis. Many people are in a situation similar to mine where they aren't able to readily afford housing. This would provide more housing which would help drive down prices.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
Bringing down housing costs and increasing diversity in neighborhood and schools, as well as saving areas from urban sprawl.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
Yes, I believe it would bring down housing costs for everyone.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
I think it would encourage neighborhood diversity, which would improve the quality of life, Plus, the increase in foot traffic would lower the need for vehicle traffic
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
I think it will decrease traffic congestion and increase use of public transportation
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
I thinking they should be encouraging it and making policies that make it easier to increase housing density
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
I think it would be a positive for the environment because it would decrease traffic and urban sprawl, leaving more natural spaces.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
It will greatly bring down costs of housing, but it would be expensive up front to implement.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think that current residents should be concerned about urban sprawl and traffic congestion. I realize that bringing down housing costs might also bring down property values, but current residents should have a little say in where exactly the new taller buildings would be built.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
I think they play a huge role. Access to home ownership or decreased housing costs gives families a chance to build wealth and increase social equity.

Is the effect of Housing shortage on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It takes time for the shortage alleviation to develop, but in the long term it would have a very strong positiive influence on the housing shortage

Does Affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Affordability has a positive effect on support for upzoning. People make decisions based on their bottom line an if they can get their housing for a more affordable cost, they will be more willing to support it.

Is the effect of Higher density housing on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it takes time to develop. I think in the short term it would have a negative effect on support because people wouldn't be seeing the benefits quickly, but in the long term, after people have a chance to experience the improvement in the housing shortage they would start to support upzoning.

What do you think are the main causes of Support for Upzoning, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
I think the main causes of support are concern for the environment and concern for the housing shortage. These are positive.

How confident are you that changes in Housing affordability lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I am fairly confident that affordability would increase support for upzoning. I think it would take some time for some people to see the benefit to themselves, but in the long run would come to understand that it is a positive thing.

How confident are you that changes in Quality of Life lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I am very confident that an improvement in quality of life, for instance more affordable housing and positive impacts on the environment would lead to support. I think that in the initial stages, the actual development and building would cause some decrease in support, but in the long run it would be obvious that upzoning increases quality of life

Would small changes in Decrease in traffic congestion lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it would take larger shifts. People would need to see how it benefits them personally, but the ability to have more foot traffic than vehicle traffic would quickly become a positive benefit of upzoning.

Would small changes in Encouraging housing development lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that at first small changes would slightly increase support

Does Environmental Concerns have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that environmental concerns, for instance decreasing traffic congestion and limiting urban sprawl would produce a moderate increase in support

How confident are you that changes in Traffic Reduction lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I am fairly confident that it will lead to support increasing, traffic congestion and pollution from vehicles is a big issue in urban areas

How would you describe the relationship between Reduction in housing costs and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it's a strong connection and that it would have a positive effect. I think it would be a moderate effect at first but become stronger over time

How would you describe the relationship between Traffic congestion and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I don't think it's as strong as it should be. People in the US are more used to the convenience of using their own vehicles rather than using public transportaiton

Does Social Equity have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Social equity has a moderately positive effect on support.

How would you describe the relationship between Home Ownership and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it is a strong connection and that current homeowners are less likely to support upzoning because they don't see it as a positive thing for them

Would small changes in Long-term positive influence lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that positive influence would lead to more support for upzoning. I think it would be a moderate effect
What might lead to increases or decreases in Upzoning policies, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
I think that government outreach and education would increase support for upzoning policies. The effects would be significant in my opinion and would be positive
What might lead to increases or decreases in Upzoning policies, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Is it working? I can't tell if it's working. Yes.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
I will probably type, but I might do voice recording too.

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
i'm trying the typing tool now

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes, I feel comfortable.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Sounds good.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I pretty much oppose that. The neighborhood that I live in is currently doing this, and we already have schools, it's completely full, car lines are out of control, traffic is terrible, and I understand the reasoning behind it, but it feels wrong to put in single family neighborhoods.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

It's negative from a mother and family point of view. I'm sure businesses like it. I'm sure property tax collectors like it. But I feel like it's taking away the greenery from the neighborhood that we had and just making it more stressful to go anywhere. It's so busy.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

I don't know. They always say it could reduce costs, but even one-bedroom apartments where I live cost $1,800, which is what my mortgage is, so I don't see just them building upward isn't going to make it cheaper. It'll probably cost just as much, but just triple our traffic.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

Quality of life will go down because everybody is out and I don't live in a walkable city. We all drive So you put a thousand people into an up zoned building and now there's a thousand cars so that just Brings down quality of life Character. Yeah, I mean it's kind of an eyesore, but they could build really nice quality luxury ones, I suppose
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

My county and my city don't have any transportation systems. There are no buses, no nothing, so traffic congestion is already pretty bad and you add more of these up zonings, which they're doing, and it's already made a negative impact and how long it takes to get somewhere and we all have to drive.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

I believe local and federal should have a say in this. You shouldn't just be allowed to say yes to all of this when everyone who lives here says no and we already have some of the highest property taxes in our state of Georgia. So I feel like our government should listen to us and do their job.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

This is where government pretends they care. They're trying to build a gigantic data center in the city next to me, same county, and they had a bajillion people show up and fight this over and over again and it's still being approved. Yeah, environmental concerns definitely factor in, but anyone who puts their hand out to collect money for this deal is going to say yes.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

For business owners, it's probably good for them because more people in the same small area, the more chances you have of people visiting your restaurant or your store. So from that aspect, it's good for business owners. It's just not good for the people who actually live here, work here, drive here.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

think the interest of current residents should be the heaviest balance. It pisses me off when you have tons of us showing up at these town halls, showing up at these hearings, and we're all together saying no please, and they completely ignore us and pass this crap anyway. Then the stuff gets built, more people come, there's more traffic, but our property taxes have gone up every single year regardless of all this. You're taking in tons more property taxes from all those housing developments you've built. Why is my single-family home taxes going up every year? It's BS.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

I think this is a tool that people who make money off of building this crap pretends that it helps with equity and access. It absolutely does not. They're not building government housing or anything like that. These places are like luxury, luxury apartments. They cost more than my house to live in. So I think it's a load of crap when people pretend that this somehow eases the burden for people who can't find homes. It's not that people can't find homes. It's that people aren't paid enough to afford them anymore and inflation has made it even harder. Pay people more and don't inflate the cost of everything. My house price has doubled in seven years. That's ridiculous.

Is the effect of Higher density housing on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think some effects are immediate traffic, for example. Others will take time to develop. Like, does this potentially bring more crime? Does this potentially bring a de-beautification of the roadsides? All these cars, are they throwing out trash? Did we hire more people to help clean up that trash? That sort of thing. It's like that broken window effect, you know, it could, you know, one broken window, the next house, let theirs go without repair. And the next thing you know, your whole neighborhood looks like that.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Support for Upzoning, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

You could increase support for upzoning by actually making these houses super affordable, obviously. You could make the support for upzoning increase exponentially by very much so lowering the property taxes that we are all currently paying in this county. I've mentioned before ours are almost the highest in Georgia, if not the highest, and they go up every year. The influence would be positive if you brought down costs.

Is the effect of Housing affordability on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Yeah, if you advertise, hey, you know, one-bedroom apartments cost $1,800, these new up-zoned buildings are going to cost $1,000 a month, you would have a ton of support for that right away from people who are struggling to afford to live, which is probably over half the country. So in that way, it would be a positive effect by decreasing costs. There is no positive effect for costs going up. People are struggling.

Does Traffic congestion have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Where I live, traffic congestion was already a big problem. It has become a massive problem over the last seven years. They are building tons of apartment complexes, and they are now starting to upzone, like our Costco is upzoning. The effect on traffic congestion is extremely significant. It definitely decreases support for upzoning, I think, for obvious reasons. One of the main reasons.

How would you describe the relationship between Local government role and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The relationship between local government and support for upzoning is direct. I feel like there must be kickbacks or something because our local government completely ignores everyone who lives here, every one of our voices. They completely tune us out and they just approve everything. Tons of gas stations, tons of liquor stores, tons of apartment complexes that literally none of us want. It's a pretty strong connection between local government and upzoning support.

How confident are you that changes in Public opposition lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, the public are the ones who have to live with these upzoning changes. So if you don't have public support for upzoning, you're going to have public opposition. They are inverse of each other. Make it affordable, somehow decrease traffic, and you would increase public support. But that's not what they're doing. It's going to remain negative.

Is the effect of Increased population density on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think the effect is pretty immediate. You know, you build 10 apartment complexes, each one holds 200 apartments, and bam, that's all in a three-mile area. Now guess what? People are living there and driving from there. They're all on the roads with us and they weren't here a year ago. That's definitely going to have a negative effect on support. Population density is an issue.

How would you describe the relationship between Property taxes and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Strong connection. For sure our property taxes are crazy high. They are building all this crap and our property taxes still go up every year. They haven't lowered them at all even though they're bringing in millions more with all the housing that they've built and filled. It's really not fair and they do nothing about it even though we all do use our voice.

Would small changes in Town hall participation lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It seems to make no difference. We used to have tiny town hall participation, if they even held town halls. Over the last five years, participation in town halls and hearings has exploded because of social media. We organize, we plan, we voice our concerns and we come prepared in absolute opposition to the continuously saying yes to every single apartment complex and up zone. I don't know what it would take. We have voted certain people out and they continue to say yes and put their hand out. I don't know how you stop that. It's a pretty strong effect and problem.

How would you describe the relationship between Luxury Apartments and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think obviously luxury apartments are more desirable to look at and have in your community than cheaper apartments or builder grade everything or government housing. I don't think any of these have a positive effect. None of these things are wanted where I live. So I'm not I'm not really sure how you would improve on that when people don't want this. We prefer single-family homes. I don't know why we can't build normal starter single-family homes like we used to back when boomers were buying homes. Why does everything have to be crammed all together?

Is the effect of Affordability of Homes on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I don't think anyone believes this is going to make housing more affordable. This is just a lie they tell us to get this stuff passed and pushed through. The reason I say that is because they have built a crap ton of apartment complexes in my county over the past few years, but home prices and apartment rentals have all gone up and property taxes have continued to go up. So they're saying that it's going to affect the affordability of homes in a positive way is not truthful. No one trusts it and it's not going to build support because we know we're being lied to.

How would you describe the relationship between Immediate effects and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Immediate effects, if they're positive, probably increase support for upzoning. But overall, I just think it's a negative. It's not something that the suburbs wanted. We don't live in a giant city. We didn't want our suburbs to become that way. So it's a negative effect overall, regardless of how they spin it.

How would you describe the relationship between Upzoning support and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I don't understand that question, the relationship between upzoning support and support for upzoning. I guess they're inverse, right? Because people don't want it.

What do you think are the main causes of Upzoning policies, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I think the main causes are money. They must get a lot of money for the city when they pass this stuff and let these things be built. I don't know what the transparency is on that. I've not looked it up, but I assume there must be a positive for government officials who say yes to this stuff or they wouldn't say yes to everything. Like they live in these communities too. They can drive the streets and see that it's not desirable to have this stuff, so I'm not really sure why all the yes. I'm not sure what is the main cause if not money or gain in some way.

How confident are you that changes in Negative effect lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Negative effects absolutely lead to less support for upzoning. I'm very confident in that. You know, more traffic, that's a negative. Lessened support. More trash on the roads, potentially more crime. Schools are now too full and so your kid has to go to class in an un-air-conditioned trailer because their school can't hold the number of new, the number of students who've come since we've built all this. Negative effects definitely decrease support. Positive effects would increase support.

Does Population density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Population density is definitely an issue. I don't see how packing even more people into a smaller area with up zoning is going to help that problem. So I don't really understand why they word it that way. It's not, you know, these people don't live here now. You're building all this stuff to bring them here. I think there's other ways that we could deal with population density and the lack of affordable housing. There's other ways to do this besides this model.

Does Population density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

qaPairs.answer: Is it working? I can't tell if it's working. Yes.

qaPairs.answer: Yes, I feel comfortable.

Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. qaPairs.answer: Sounds good.

qaPairs.question: Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
qaPairs.answer: Okay.

qaPairs.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
qaPairs.answer: I pretty much oppose that. The neighborhood that I live in is currently doing this, and we already have schools, it's completely full, car lines are out of control, traffic is terrible, and I understand the reasoning behind it, but it feels wrong to put in single family neighborhoods.

qaPairs.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
qaPairs.answer: It's negative from a mother and family point of view. I'm sure businesses like it. I'm sure property tax collectors like it. But I feel like it's taking away the greenery from the neighborhood that we had and just making it more stressful to go anywhere. It's so busy.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
qaPairs.answer: I don't know. They always say it could reduce costs, but even one-bedroom apartments where I live cost $1,800, which is what my mortgage is, so I don't see just them building upward isn't going to make it cheaper. It'll probably cost just as much, but just triple our traffic.

qaPairs.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
qaPairs.answer: Quality of life will go down because everybody is out and I don't live in a walkable city. We all drive So you put a thousand people into an up zoned building and now there's a thousand cars so that just Brings down quality of life Character. Yeah, I mean it's kind of an eyesore, but they could build really nice quality luxury ones, I suppose

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
qaPairs.answer: My county and my city don't have any transportation systems. There are no buses, no nothing, so traffic congestion is already pretty bad and you add more of these up zonings, which they're doing, and it's already made a negative impact and how long it takes to get somewhere and we all have to drive.

qaPairs.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
qaPairs.answer: I believe local and federal should have a say in this. You shouldn't just be allowed to say yes to all of this when everyone who lives here says no and we already have some of the highest property taxes in our state of Georgia. So I feel like our government should listen to us and do their job.

qaPairs.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
qaPairs.answer: This is where government pretends they care. They're trying to build a gigantic data center in the city next to me, same county, and they had a bajillion people show up and fight this over and over again and it's still being approved. Yeah, environmental concerns definitely factor in, but anyone who puts their hand out to collect money for this deal is going to say yes.

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: For business owners, it's probably good for them because more people in the same small area, the more chances you have of people visiting your restaurant or your store. So from that aspect, it's good for business owners. It's just not good for the people who actually live here, work here, drive here.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: think the interest of current residents should be the heaviest balance. It pisses me off when you have tons of us showing up at these town halls, showing up at these hearings, and we're all together saying no please, and they completely ignore us and pass this crap anyway. Then the stuff gets built, more people come, there's more traffic, but our property taxes have gone up every single year regardless of all this. You're taking in tons more property taxes from all those housing developments you've built. Why is my single-family home taxes going up every year? It's BS.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer: I think this is a tool that people who make money off of building this crap pretends that it helps with equity and access. It absolutely does not. They're not building government housing or anything like that. These places are like luxury, luxury apartments. They cost more than my house to live in. So I think it's a load of crap when people pretend that this somehow eases the burden for people who can't find homes. It's not that people can't find homes. It's that people aren't paid enough to afford them anymore and inflation has made it even harder. Pay people more and don't inflate the cost of everything. My house price has doubled in seven years. That's ridiculous.

I think some effects are immediate traffic, for example. Others will take time to develop. Like, does this potentially bring more crime? Does this potentially bring a de-beautification of the roadsides? All these cars, are they throwing out trash? Did we hire more people to help clean up that trash? That sort of thing. It's like that broken window effect, you know, it could, you know, one broken window, the next house, let theirs go without repair. And the next thing you know, your whole neighborhood looks like that.

Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
yeah
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I generally support upzoning because it helps make housing more affordable and cities more sustainable. Allowing higher-density housing in single-family neighborhoods can ease the housing crisis, reduce urban sprawl, and make communities more diverse and vibrant. Plus, itâ€™s better for the environment since it encourages public transit use.

That said, upzoning can also cause pushback from residents worried about losing the neighborhoodâ€™s character or dealing with overcrowded infrastructure. It can even lead to displacement if not done thoughtfully. So, while Iâ€™m for it, I think cities should plan carefully and include community input to make it work for everyone.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

Increasing housing density makes cities more affordable and sustainable while boosting local businesses and public transit use. The downside is it can strain infrastructure and change neighborhood character if not managed well. Balancing growth and community identity is crucial.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

Upzoning policies can boost housing affordability by increasing the supply of homes, which helps ease demand and lower prices. However, if new developments focus on luxury units, affordability might not improve. The key is balancing new housing types with protections against displacement.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

Increased housing density can make neighborhoods more vibrant and lively, with more shops, services, and public transit options. However, it can also change the areaâ€™s character, leading to concerns about overcrowding, noise, and loss of the original community feel. Balancing growth with preserving local identity is essential.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

Upzoning can reduce car dependence if itâ€™s paired with good public transit, bike lanes, and walkable infrastructure. However, without these improvements, increased density might worsen traffic congestion and strain existing transit systems. Thoughtful urban planning is key to making it work.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

Local governments should balance encouraging housing development with preserving community character and affordability. They should set clear zoning rules, ensure infrastructure keeps up with growth, and protect vulnerable residents from displacement. Involving the community in planning decisions is also crucial.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

Environmental concerns are a big factorâ€”higher urban density can reduce sprawl, cut car use, and lower carbon emissions, making cities more sustainable. However, it also puts pressure on green spaces and can increase heat and pollution if not well-planned. Balancing density with green infrastructure is key.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

Allowing more multi-family housing can boost the local economy by attracting more residents who support businesses and increase tax revenue. It can also make housing more affordable, drawing in workers. However, it might raise property values, potentially pricing out existing residents and small businesses if not managed carefully.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think itâ€™s about finding a middle ground. Current residents want to protect what they love about their neighborhood, and thatâ€™s totally understandable. But we also have to make room for new people who need affordable places to live. The best approach is to listen to everyone, be open about whatâ€™s coming, and work together to make sure growth feels fair and doesnâ€™t erase the communityâ€™s spirit.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

Social equity and access to opportunity are central to zoning and housing policy because where people live affects their access to good schools, jobs, transit, and a safe environment. Thoughtful zoning can help create more inclusive neighborhoods that offer everyone a fair chance to thrive. Without considering equity, policies risk deepening segregation and inequality. So, balancing growth with fairness means making sure new housing benefits all kinds of peopleâ€”not just the wealthyâ€”while protecting vulnerable communities from displacement.

In the end, zoning isnâ€™t just about buildings; itâ€™s about building fairer, more connected communities where everyone has a shot at a better life.

How confident are you that changes in Affordable housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Better affordable housing generally boosts support for upzoning because it shows real benefits. The effect is positive but varies depending on how well affordable housing is delivered. If upzoning doesnâ€™t lead to affordability, support may stay low.
What factors affect Support for Upzoning, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Support for upzoning goes up with affordable housing, good community input, and environmental benefits. It goes down with fears of displacement, traffic, loss of neighborhood feel, and distrust in officials. The biggest factors are affordable housing (up) and displacement fears (down).

How would you describe the relationship between Public transit use and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
can we get to the bottom of this

Is the effect of Balancing growth and community identity on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effect of balancing growth and community identity on support for upzoning usually takes time to develop. When done well, it has a positive effect because people feel their neighborhoodâ€™s character is respected. The strength of this effect can be quite strong, especially if the process is transparent and inclusiveâ€”helping build lasting trust and acceptance.

Rushing or ignoring this balance can backfire and decrease support. So patience and care are key.

How would you describe the relationship between Displacement and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Displacement has a **strong negative** effect on support for upzoning. When people worry that upzoning will push them out or raise their costs, they tend to oppose it. This connection is one of the most powerful factors reducing support, especially in vulnerable communities.

Addressing displacement fears is crucial to gaining broader backing for upzoning policies.

How would you describe the relationship between Supply of homes and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The relationship between the supply of homes and support for upzoning is generally positive and moderately strong. When upzoning clearly increases housing supply, people tend to support it more because it helps address affordability and availability. However, the effect isnâ€™t always immediate or guaranteedâ€”it depends on whether the new supply actually meets local needs.

So, more housing supply usually boosts support, but the strength varies based on outcomes.

Is the effect of Public Transit on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
youre asking me almost the same questions

Is the effect of Car dependence on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effect of car dependence on support for upzoning usually takes time to develop. If upzoning reduces the need for cars by improving walkability and transit, support grows positively but gradually as people experience the benefits.

If car dependence stays high or worsens, it can negatively impact support due to increased traffic and frustration. Overall, this effect is moderateâ€”important but slower to influence opinions.

Is the effect of Urban planning on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effect of urban planning on support for upzoning usually takes time to develop. Good planning that involves the community and improves infrastructure gradually increases support by addressing concerns.

On the other hand, poor or rushed planning can quickly lead to negative reactions and lower support. Overall, this effect is strongâ€”careful planning is essential for lasting acceptance.

How would you describe the relationship between Preserving affordability and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

How would you describe the relationship between Sprawl reduction and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The relationship between sprawl reduction and support for upzoning is generally positive but relatively moderate. People who value limiting urban sprawl tend to support upzoning because it encourages denser, more efficient use of land.

However, this connection isnâ€™t always very strong since not everyone prioritizes sprawl issues when forming opinions on upzoning. So, it increases support but with a moderate effect.

Does Balancing density have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Balancing density has a positive effect on support for upzoning. When density is managed wellâ€”so growth feels thoughtful and respects the neighborhoodâ€”it increases trust and acceptance. This effect is fairly strong because people are more comfortable supporting changes that donâ€™t overwhelm their community.

How confident are you that changes in Support for Local Businesses lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Iâ€™m moderately confident that changes in support for local businesses influence support for upzoning. Generally, if people believe upzoning helps local businesses by bringing in more customers, it has a positive effect on support.

However, if upzoning is seen as harming small businessesâ€”through displacement or rising costsâ€”it can decrease support. Overall, this effect is moderate but less strong compared to factors like affordable housing or displacement concerns.

How confident are you that changes in Open communication lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Iâ€™m very confident that open communication has a positive effect on support for upzoning. When local governments and developers communicate clearly and involve the community, trust builds and support tends to increase.

This effect is strong because people are more willing to back changes when they feel heard and informed, reducing fears and misunderstandings.

Is the effect of Access to Opportunity on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effect of access to opportunity on support for upzoning usually takes time to develop. When upzoning helps create neighborhoods with better schools, jobs, and transit, support grows positively but gradually as people experience these benefits.

Overall, this effect is moderately strong because real improvements in opportunity build trust and long-term support.
What factors do you think influence Public transit use, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Public transit use goes up when there are lots of people nearby, the service is reliable, stops are easy to get to, and fares are affordable. It drops when people rely on cars, service is bad, or neighborhoods are spread out. The biggest factors are how many people live close by and how good the transit is.

How confident are you that changes in Fears of displacement lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Iâ€™m very confident that fears of displacement have a strong negative effect on support for upzoning. When people worry they might be pushed out or priced out, theyâ€™re much less likely to support upzoning policies.

Addressing these fears is key to gaining wider community support.

How would you describe the relationship between Positive effect and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Would small changes in Strong Negative Effect lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Small changes in a strong negative effect like fears of displacement can lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning. Even modest reductions in those fears can meaningfully increase support.

The effect is negative (fears decrease support), but easing those fears has a positive impact on backing upzoning. Overall, the effect is strong and sensitiveâ€”small improvements matter a lot.

qaPairs.answer: Environmental concerns are a big factorâ€”higher urban density can reduce sprawl, cut car use, and lower carbon emissions, making cities more sustainable. However, it also puts pressure on green spaces and can increase heat and pollution if not well-planned. Balancing density with green infrastructure is key.

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: Allowing more multi-family housing can boost the local economy by attracting more residents who support businesses and increase tax revenue. It can also make housing more affordable, drawing in workers. However, it might raise property values, potentially pricing out existing residents and small businesses if not managed carefully.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: I think itâ€™s about finding a middle ground. Current residents want to protect what they love about their neighborhood, and thatâ€™s totally understandable. But we also have to make room for new people who need affordable places to live. The best approach is to listen to everyone, be open about whatâ€™s coming, and work together to make sure growth feels fair and doesnâ€™t erase the communityâ€™s spirit.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer:
Social equity and access to opportunity are central to zoning and housing policy because where people live affects their access to good schools, jobs, transit, and a safe environment. Thoughtful zoning can help create more inclusive neighborhoods that offer everyone a fair chance to thrive. Without considering equity, policies risk deepening segregation and inequality. So, balancing growth with fairness means making sure new housing benefits all kinds of peopleâ€”not just the wealthyâ€”while protecting vulnerable communities from displacement.

In the end, zoning isnâ€™t just about buildings; itâ€™s about building fairer, more connected communities where everyone has a shot at a better life.

Better affordable housing generally boosts support for upzoning because it shows real benefits. The effect is positive but varies depending on how well affordable housing is delivered. If upzoning doesnâ€™t lead to affordability, support may stay low.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Affordable housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Affordable housing â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Support for upzoning goes up with affordable housing, good community input, and environmental benefits. It goes down with fears of displacement, traffic, loss of neighborhood feel, and distrust in officials. The biggest factors are affordable housing (up) and displacement fears (down).

Population density generally has a negative effect on support for upzoning. Since higher density can increase concerns about crowding and traffic, the effect is moderate to strong in decreasing support.
